Award.AwardTitle: Science in Alaska: Using Multimedia to Support Science Education
Award.AbstractNarration: The proposed project, which will build upon a successful NSF EAGER grant, will help arctic researchers explain the significance of their research widely to the general public?which, in today?s technologically connected world means not only in the U.S., but worldwide- and to reflect the diversity of the scientific enterprise Alaska. As proposed, the current Frontier Scientist?s schedule of science reporting will be enhanced by a broadcast TV series titled Frontier Scientists to engage a larger viewing audience. A ?Do It Yourself? (DIY) component will help scientists to create their, professional-caliber media that will sustain the publics? interest and feedback in their research. An evaluation regime will insure appropriate quality and depth of communication, throughout the lifecycle of each science story.

POR.DRECONTENT:
WonderVisions in our 3 Year Grant #1304904, titled “Science in Alaska: Using Multimedia to Support Science.” produced over 250 short videos (3-10 minutes) . The videos reside on the Frontier Scientists YouTube channel and on the web site www.FrontierScientists.com .  We delivered two seasons of 30 minute programs broadcast on the Alaska PBS TV.  Because of popular demand by scientists to learn media techniques, we conducted two scientists’ workshops at the American Geophysical Union conference and at the University of Alaska Fairbanks. We produced videos with 95 scientists, 24 were women. We blogged weekly [160 original blogs], Tweeted daily, and distributed a press release monthly to highlight new videos or events. We presented FS work-in-progress twice in oral talks at the AGU conference, built a web-associated App and a game titled “Arctic UAV’s,” (available in Itunes and google playstore) and presented the game at conferences in Washington DC, Arctic Matters Day, Nov. 2015 and The Arctic Science Ministerial STEM Education event in September 2016.

Frontier Scientists’ filming process fosters a close collaboration between the scientist and the media maker. FS helps scientists reach out to the public, communicate the relevance of their scientific findings. Videos keep audience tuned in; combining field footage, pictures, audio, and graphics with a verbal explanation helps illustrate ideas, allowing one video to reach people with different learning strategies. The scientists’ stories are highlighted through social media platforms online.

 

FS grant scientists a voice, ensuring accuracy. Each scientific topic on FS has its own project page where easy-to-navigate videos are featured prominently. Video sets focus on different aspects of a researcher’s work or follow one of their projects into the field. Videos are accompanied by written blogs intended to systematically demystify related facts so the scientists can focus on presenting what they’re passionate about, not get bogged down by basic groundwork. Short video bios showcase the enthusiasm and personality of the scientists, an important ingredient in crafting compelling videos.

 

Featured scientists become better communicators, and learn to bring their research to life. When viewers see their genuine wonder, they can be motivated to ask questions and pursue more information about the topic, broadening community participation. Digital media is a community builder, an inclusive tool that lets people continents-apart engage with compelling stories and then interact.

 

Science for Tourists in Alaska

Frontier Scientists joined “Visit Anchorage,” a tourism hub in Alaska. FS made presentations at a number of volunteer meetings to inform the volunteers about the website and broadcast programs, so they could pass the word along to tourists. The short videos were of interest to business members of the organization, who sent links to tourists before they came to Alaska to allow them to better understand the rural areas they were traveling through or visiting.

Significant Results

Over the past three years Frontier Scientists has achieved a number of results that surprised us as well as a number of other professionals.

  • Our Frontier Scientists web site consistently built an audience.  Our social media efforts brought in people from Facebook, YouTube, Twitter, Pinterest etc.
  • We worked with University of Alaska Fairbanks undergraduates on building a FS App and creating a video game titled Arctic UAV’s.  Over the three year project we worked with five different students.  Liz O’Connell arranged for outside experts to phone conference with specific advice to accomplish goals.  Jay Byam, upon graduating, secured a job with one of the companies we consulted. 
  • The broadcast programs in the Frontier Scientists series began building an audience on public TV in Alaska.  The Nielsen ratings Frontier Scientists received indicates there is a public audience appetite for science programs about the Arctic with not so famous scientists.
  • Three woman scientists we created videos with have significant achievements: Gwen Holdmann and Tamara Harms, University of Alaska Fairbanks, were selected as Arctic Fulbright scholars announced, April 21, 2015. Karyn Rode, USGS wildlife researcher, will be on Science Friday sometime in March 2017.  
  • The workshops for scientists, educators, and professionals provided hands-on learning, experience, discussion of methods and best practices for a professional product.
  • Videos have been used as reference for grants, thesis papers, and job applications.  We believe because often times a person who has not been in the arctic has a difficult time understanding the scientists working conditions and the working capabilities of the equipment in a field situation.  The videos show and tell more than just a written description of the materials and methods.
  • Laura Nielsen was not a science writer before she began the Frontier Scientist project but over the past 4 years she has written most of the FS blogs and has become a quick study for the variety of science topics FS covers.
  • The project results have been disseminated by a final evaluation by PEER associates residing on the CAISE web site.
